trans-unit.source: Manage your Azure VMs using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage your Azure VMs using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how to create, manage, and delete your Azure VMs using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to create, manage, and delete your Azure VMs using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows.

trans-unit.source: Manage your Virtual Machines using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows
trans-unit.target: Manage your Virtual Machines using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows

trans-unit.source: Many tasks you do each day to manage your VMs can by automated by using the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Many tasks you do each day to manage your VMs can by automated by using the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: This article gives you example commands for simpler tasks, and links to articles that show the commands for more complex tasks.
trans-unit.target: This article gives you example commands for simpler tasks, and links to articles that show the commands for more complex tasks.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you haven't installed and configured the Azure CLI yet, you can get instructions [here](../xplat-cli-install.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you haven't installed and configured the Azure CLI yet, you can get instructions [here](../xplat-cli-install.md).

trans-unit.source: If you want a quickstart for the same tasks in PowerShell, see [Manage your VMs using Azure PowerShell](virtual-machines-manage-vms-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: If you want a quickstart for the same tasks in PowerShell, see [Manage your VMs using Azure PowerShell](virtual-machines-manage-vms-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: How to Use the Example Commands
trans-unit.target: How to Use the Example Commands

trans-unit.source: You'll need to replace some of the text in the commands with text that's appropriate for your environment.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to replace some of the text in the commands with text that's appropriate for your environment.

trans-unit.source: The < and > symbols indicate text you need to replace.
trans-unit.target: The < and > symbols indicate text you need to replace.

trans-unit.source: When you replace the text, remove the symbols but leave the quote marks in place.
trans-unit.target: When you replace the text, remove the symbols but leave the quote marks in place.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to programmatically store and manipulate the output of your console commands, you may want to use a JSON parsing tool such as **[jq](https://github.com/stedolan/jq)**, **[jsawk](https://github.com/micha/jsawk)**, or language libraries good for the task.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to programmatically store and manipulate the output of your console commands, you may want to use a JSON parsing tool such as **[jq](https://github.com/stedolan/jq)**, **[jsawk](https://github.com/micha/jsawk)**, or language libraries good for the task.

trans-unit.source: Show information about a VM
trans-unit.target: Show information about a VM

trans-unit.source: This is a basic task you'll use often.
trans-unit.target: This is a basic task you'll use often.

trans-unit.source: Use it to get information about a VM, perform tasks on a VM, or get output to store in a variable.
trans-unit.target: Use it to get information about a VM, perform tasks on a VM, or get output to store in a variable.

trans-unit.source: To get info about the VM, run this command, replacing everything in the quotes, including the < and > characters:
trans-unit.target: To get info about the VM, run this command, replacing everything in the quotes, including the < and > characters:

trans-unit.source: To store the output in a $vm variable as a JSON document, run:
trans-unit.target: To store the output in a $vm variable as a JSON document, run:

trans-unit.source: or you can pipe the stdout to a file.
trans-unit.target: or you can pipe the stdout to a file.

trans-unit.source: Log on to a Linux-based virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Log on to a Linux-based virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Typically Linux machines are connected to through SSH.
trans-unit.target: Typically Linux machines are connected to through SSH.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure](virtual-machines-linux-use-ssh-key.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [How to Use SSH with Linux on Azure](virtual-machines-linux-use-ssh-key.md).

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager Overview
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager Overview

trans-unit.source: Stop a VM
trans-unit.target: Stop a VM

trans-unit.source: Run this command:
trans-unit.target: Run this command:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Use this parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] Use this parameter to keep the virtual IP (VIP) of the cloud service in case it's the last VM in that cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you use the StayProvisioned parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.
trans-unit.target: If you use the StayProvisioned parameter, you'll still be billed for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Start a VM
trans-unit.target: Start a VM

trans-unit.source: Run this command:
trans-unit.target: Run this command:

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager Overview
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager Overview

trans-unit.source: azure vm start
trans-unit.target: azure vm start

trans-unit.source: Attach a Data Disk
trans-unit.target: Attach a Data Disk

trans-unit.source: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.
trans-unit.target: You'll also need to decide whether to attach a new disk or one that contains data.

trans-unit.source: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it in the same command.
trans-unit.target: For a new disk, the command creates the .vhd file and attaches it in the same command.

trans-unit.source: To attach a new disk, run this command:
trans-unit.target: To attach a new disk, run this command:

trans-unit.source: To attach an existing data disk, run this command:
trans-unit.target: To attach an existing data disk, run this command:

trans-unit.source: Create a Linux VM
trans-unit.target: Create a Linux VM

trans-unit.source: To create a new Linux-based VM, you're going to need to have several values on hand, including a resource group name, a location, an image name, a vm name, and a storage account to store the backing .vhd image.
trans-unit.target: To create a new Linux-based VM, you're going to need to have several values on hand, including a resource group name, a location, an image name, a vm name, and a storage account to store the backing .vhd image.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the information you want to use, the Azure CLI can create an interactive session to prompt you for those values by typing:
trans-unit.target: Once you have the information you want to use, the Azure CLI can create an interactive session to prompt you for those values by typing:

trans-unit.source: Of course, if you already have those values you can find the proper switches to pass them directly by typing `azure help vm create`.
trans-unit.target: Of course, if you already have those values you can find the proper switches to pass them directly by typing `azure help vm create`.

trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.target: For far more examples of Azure CLI usage with the **arm** mode, see [Using the Microsoft Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Resource Management](../xplat-cli-resource-manager.md).

trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure resources and their concepts, see [Azure Resource Manager Overview](../resource-group-overview.md).
